People ought to read the linked-to articles. (Also, Andy could have noted which solar technology is to be used). Solar energy captured with mirrors is far more thermodynamically efficient that solar energy captured by solar cells. Energy storage comes naturally, and the bigger the plant, the more efficient the storage, because volume (and energy stored) goes as R^3 while surface area (and heat loss) goes as R^2. With a big-enough tank of molten salt, the energy can be stored for weeks. The technology is not mature and the costs per megawatt are not comparable to mature technology (as #16 Gene G pointed out), and the plant is far smaller than a maximally efficient plant would be.

James #18, a Nevada resident, complains about "thousands of acres." Ten thousand acres covers a square four miles on a side. It will generate energy forever (barring climate change).

Maturing technology will require less frequent overhauls. Compared to nuclear, which generates neutrons that destroy the materials of the plant, equipment life could be much longer. High-voltage DC transmission lines (made feasible by power semiconductors) will permit transmission of this energy over long distances.

And, in any case, what the economy needs now (with high unemployment and target interest rates required to bring the unemployment down at negative 6%), is spending which leaves the dollars in U.S. consumer hands. This solar project accomplishes that while producing a permanent useful public work (including not only the plant itself regardless of who owns it, but the know-how developed by building it).

Great discussion from professionals who live this everyday as well as opinions about costs and containment. All very necessary. I believe that "aging in place" can be an overrated concept. But, I have never seen property as an asset, only that it "owns" you the way it is practiced in modern US. My parents bought into this concept 100%. It can be a matter of pride and socialization. It can be costly in the terms of isolation, transportation, and worry for the frail elder. Sometimes, letting an individual design their own demise is the only thing that a family can do if the elder remains stubborn. After all, if one owns property and is still considered legally functional, the law is clear on human property rights.

I live in a very comfortable independent living complex in Northern CA. The community reflects a lot of different generational cultural values, ages, and diversity in ethnic elders. There are many advantages to living in smaller spaces that still maintain independence and privacy. But, our "American" dream pushes most people towards the value of home ownership. Lately, it has become the American nightmare just like the approaching plethora of "baby boomers" who are not as flexible as stated earlier. This will be another financial nightmare unless compromises are reached and people forget that it isn't always about "them" but about other younger generations, financial feasibility, and our ecosystem.

The discourse on this thread has been delightfully thoughtful. In fact, it has reinforced my feelings about the basic goodness of our species.

As far as human life going on indefinitely, I've no objection. We'll have a lot of thinking and changing to do so that we can make the appropriate adjustments; that's for sure. We do need to keep ourselves as healthy and vigorous as possible. That's a matter of personal responsibility. The better we take care of ourselves, the more resources available for those who can't.

This retirement business is a bunch of hokum anyway – especially the ages tossed about, 55, for instance – give me break! Doing nothing but watch the grass grow to assure yourself you'll have something to do the following week is silly. I can't see the purpose of life to be amassing enough wealth to sit around for 20 worrisome years watching a bank account dwindle.

Find something you love to do, something that doesn't harm the health and safety of our beautiful planet, something that pays the bills and stocks the pantry, and work, work, work. Live, live, live!

This is a great story showing how indepence can be maintained. I wish everyone could be in this situation! There are a number of new technologies that can help with the indepence and help to reduce hospital visits.

Receiving care "in the home" does not necessarily mean receiving it in the house you've lived in for 50 years. My mother gets a monthly visit from superb nurse practitioners in the condo she shares with my husband and me. Mom will be 94 later this month and is extremly frail from years of rheumatoid arthritis. These home visits have been one of the most wonderful things to happen to us in the five years that she has lived with us.

I enthusiastically second the commenters who point out that quality house calls can be provided by health professionals other than MDs.
We need more physicians like Dr.Peter Boling teaching our med students...

Home visits are extremely valuable. I have a unique position in the health care system that provides me with the opportunity to work in both the emergency department at the local hospital and in the community seeing clients/patients in their home (house, condo, senior living community, hospice, etc). I agree 110% with the author... you learn more about how the person is managing in 5 minutes at home than 5 hours in the ER. Someone's ability to manage safely at home has as much to do with their physical environment (and social supports such as friends/family) as it does with their physical health. Focus needs to be about making sure their physical/cognitive/social/emotional abilities are appropriately matched with their surroundings at home. Not only do home visits save money, they also ensure the safety of our clients/patients.

http://www.caring-for-aging-parents.com

It's great that you raise the basic moral quandary, as failing to do just that does seem indeed how we get into the unending tragedies people seem prone to creating.

If people live longer they will necessarily have longer and longer unproductive lives and consume more and more resources with increasingly costly healthcare, and on a finite planet... leaving less and less room on the earth for the other people.

So, improving health with providing longer periods of increasingly expensive medical care worsens the population problem in numerous ways it seems.

The way do the calculations is using money as the accurate measure of impacts, 6000btu/$ is the average around the world for the total resource consumed by the economy, the general correspondence between nature's "universal resource" and ours.

So, our real impacts are how much we earn, and how much we expect others to earn to support us when we can't, living on a planet where all our resources are in measurable overshoot. The top of the list of things to change then,... is to stop wasting our money on concentrating wealth and resources for those who treat it only as a game.

I believe that while humans have evolved considerably since Homo Habilis, we're not precisely in evolution's grip anymore because we care for eachother, and fix flaws when we can. Eg: the appendix, until recently an evolutionary error (we don't need a rock-holding gizzard to digest food) that acted mostly as a self-destruct device, is still with us. But appendicitis is nearly never fatal today, and it's not because of evolution.

So, since we have no evolutionary need to lose the appendix anymore, we won't lose it like our pre-Habilis tail, or heavy fur coat.

The evolutionary need for humans to breed, then rapidly decline in health was based on them dying after their children were self-sufficient but before using up too many of their children's available resources. This doesn't apply to us now, and I think we've actually doubled our life expectancy in the past few tens of thousands of years.

So based on all this, I think we'll be living longer, but never wind up evolving out of dying by some clever mutation. And I think the scary thing about living 'too long' is really being alive while in constant pain, or too feeble to get around, or losing one's memory and mental acuity, not the number of years we'd be around.

Everyone is different. My over 80 dad (in fairly good mental and physical shape) left his assisted living facility for a private apartment not for romance but out of distaste for the company of elderly frail women. He found they had little to no interest in sports or current affairs or his reading of history.(They had been mostly housewives without college education). More importantly the walkers and canes and health aides reminded him of his mortality. He fled.
Now he is somewhat depressed by loneliness in his apartment and I fret about his vulnerability. There is no Gloria on the horizon and given my dad's gruff personality there is not likely to be one. At this point I would view the affections of any woman for him with suspicion even though his funds are limited.
